moves.1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 d: 4...Nf6 forces white along a narrower path.  As played white can transpose to a bind with c4 or not.
moves.11. f3 Bd7 12. Be3: If black gets a hold of d4, white will be very much worse for wear.
moves.12... Qa5 13. Qc2 Rac8 14. f4 Nc6 15. Nf: I have to wonder if Nxc6 was better even though it exchanges white's central knight.
moves.15... Ng4: Expected, but is still a good move.  Black threatens both bishop and knight when the white knight is suffering from a relative pin (as opposed to an absolute pin where the rules of the game prohibit the piece from moving away).
moves.16. Bd2 Qc5+: ! Diffusing the white idea with check and delivering a rather nasty idea of his own.  Black is taking advantage of weaknesses that white has created in his position.
moves.18. Rxf2: !  White will be down two pawns, but he survives with the bishop pair for now and responds to the following idea: 18.Kg1 Nxe4+ 19.Kh1 Nxd2! 20.Qxd2 Qb4!
moves.18... Qxf2 19. Rf1: Black is compelled to move, but he is ahead.
moves.20... e6 21. Be3: Need to evaluate 21.b4 as the played move seems seems to cost material.  21.b4! and the queen has no escape planned: 21...Nxb4 22.Bxb4 Qxc4! and black siezes the file but trades away his material advantage to save the queen.
moves.21... Qa3 22. Bc1: White would very much like exchanging dark-square bishops, and that threat on his knight is irksome.
moves.23... Nb4 24. Qd2 Bxc3: A good move with a dark side; It wins a pawn but it concedes the dark squares.
moves.25. Qxc3 Nxa2: Irritating, but accurate where white loses the dark squares.
moves.26. Qf6: But white wants to control the dark squares anyway.
moves.26... Nxc1: Black may believe he has removed white's teeth, but there is fight left.
moves.27. Rxc1 d5: ? And a Blunder provides the way.  I was struggling through ideas on how to pivot the knight to the square I want it on when he releases control of a key square on the path.  Up until now black was winning or the game was even.  Now the game is at least even or in white's hands.
moves.28. Ne5 Bc6: ?? Terrible.  Saves a piece at the cost of the game.  Black must defend g4.
moves.29. Ng4: Resignation, but it is premature.  White threatens mate in 1 forcing 29...h5 when it is unclear whether white will get enough compensation from 30.Nh6+ Kh7 31.Nxf7 dxe4 (as a filler move for black) 32.Ng5+ Kh6 (32...Kg8 33.Qxg6+ Kh8 34.Qxh7#).
